text: I think I need help with my laundry.

Hello washed and left out to dry, Trace here
rockin' new duds on DNews. You might think

science is something only done in labs, but
every week-or-so chances are you suspend organic

and synthetic fibers in a solution of water,
enzymes, surfactants, and detergents to confine

particulates and relax molecular bonds. In
layman's terms: you do laundry, and when you

think about it, it really is like controlled
chemistry! Unfortunately, we don't all do

this at-home science in the same way, which
is why when doing laundry, we've all messed

up a favorite sweater or shrunk a pair of
[pants?] but why do these things shrink at
all?! What's going on there?

So, firstly, there are a couple kinds of fibers
used to make clothing: synthetic and natural.

In general, synthetics are man-made polymers
like polyester, rayon, Kevlar, or acrylic.

Their fibers are strings of petroleum-based
chemical chains. Synthetics made from petroleum

products don't typically shrink in laundry
because the washer and dryer do not get hot

enough to mess with their structure. So, let's
ignore those.

Natural fibers, on the other hand, come from
animals and plants. The fibers of cotton,

wool or silk are naturally curly and tangled.
When you want to weave these threads into

fabrics, you have to stretch and pull them
to make them straight. But if given the opportunity

to return to their natural curly state they
will. And scientists have discovered the heat

and mechanical energy in laundry machines
let them do just that -- in a process called
shrinkage.

There are three kinds of shrinkage: Relaxation,
Felting, and Consolidation.

Relaxing is the immediate release of that
stretching and pulling tension left behind

from the straightening of the natural fibers.
That tension exists on a molecular level,

and is leftover from the manufacturing process.
When tepid or warm water is added to the natural

fabric, the warmth will let the fabric swell,
reducing the size by about 1 percent. Not
too shabby.

Felting shrinkage is when the fibers themselves
actually get shorter. If you magnify wool

in an electron microscope it's made of tiny
scales, just like human hair. According to

a paper in the Textile Research Journal, the
heat from the washer can expand these scales

letting water get between them. Water is slippery,
so it reduces the coefficient of friction,

and those scales slide together, contracting
rootward, like a retracting car or radio antenna!

The third type is Consolidation shrinkage,
and it happens in the laundry process itself.

The mechanical bouncing action of your washer
and drier beats up the fibers, curling them
back up again.

A 2002 study in The Research Journal of Association
of Universities for Textiles. found the structure

of the fabric affects shrinkage too. Denim
jeans are tightly-woven cotton so they only

shrink a little, but sweaters are mostly air!
So they can shrink as much as 30 percent according
to Popular Science.

Even the natural moisture content of the fibers
themselves can affect shrinkage: cotton has

about 5 percent, wool has about 17 percent,
so over-drying can will inevitably cause clothing
to change shape.

In World War II, Nazi scientists added plastics
to wool to fill in the spaces and solidify

the fibers, sometimes, and today this continues
with manufacturers weaving in non-shrinking

synthetics, and chemists inventing new anti-shrinking
agents to cover natural fibers and keep them
from curling up.

Look, scientists who did write papers on shrinkage
were quick to point out: everyone does laundry

differently. Water temperature, amount of
time, detergent, clothing fibers, and even

machine manufacturer all add variables to
to the at-home science project that is laundry.

The best way to love your clothes is to remember:
one: follow the instructions on the tag because

the people who made it know what's in there
and how to clean it, but when in doubt don't

add heat and mechanical energy. Use cold water
and avoid the dryer. And two: remember that

natural fiber clothing is made from the parts
of living things! Living things aren't supposed
to last forever. And that's okay.

We'd like to take a second and thank our sponsor
for this episode: AT and T. AT&T Digital Life

smart home security helps keep you connected
to your home, so there are no more what ifs.

Skinny jeans, sweaters, tiny t-shirts… why
am I reminded of hipsters? Oh, because they're

all the same! At least, that's what this mathematician
discovered! I did a whole video about it here,
so grab your fancy coffee and give it a click.

Do you love laundry? Hate it? Super meticulous
about it?
